learning_outcomes.description: Apply foundational knowledge in drug physiochemical properties to drug design and medicines use
Apply physiochemical principles to the formulation of liquid dosage forms and medicines use
Collate, analyse, and interpret pharmaceutical science data to inform decisions
Perform pharmaceutical calculations relating to liquid medicines
Design and prepare accurate and pharmaceutically elegant extemporaneous liquid dosage forms

assessments.task_description:
There are three online quizzes held during semester, named the 'Drug Design & Analysis Online Quiz', 'Pharmaceutical Calculations Online Quiz', and the 'Liquid Dosage Form Design Online Quiz'.

Quiz 1: Drug Design and Analysis Online Quiz (12.5% weighting):

  • ONE attempt is permitted between 19/12/2025 1:00 pm and 6/01/2026 5:00 pm.
  • The quiz questions will cover Module 1 content (i.e. Drug Analysis; Drug Design to Optimise PK/PD; Design of Biological Drugs; and the Drug Analysis Practical).
  • The quiz duration is 80 minutes. An additional 10 mins is provided as a buffer for any issues that might arise during your quiz.
  • The quiz timer is set to 90 minutes, after which your answers will be saved and submitted automatically (unless you submit them sooner manually). The timer will continue to run if you exit the quiz.


Quiz 2: Pharmaceutical Calculations Online Quiz (5% weighting):

  • THREE attempts are permitted between 22/12/2025 9:00 am and 20/01/2026 5:00 pm, with the best mark counting towards the course grade.
  • The quiz involves calculations related to compounding and dispensing liquid dosage forms.
  • The quiz duration is 80 minutes. An additional 10 mins is provided as a buffer for any issues that might arise during your quiz.
  • The quiz timer is set to 90 minutes, after which your answers will be saved and submitted automatically (unless you submit them sooner manually). The timer will continue to run if you exit the quiz.


Quiz 3: Liquid Dosage Form Design Online Quiz (12.5% weighting):

  • ONE attempt is permitted between 23/01/2026 1:00 pm and 30/01/2026 5:00 pm.
  • The quiz questions will cover Module 2 content (i.e. Solutions; Buffers, Cosolvents, and Complexation; Dispersions; Drug Stability; and the Dispersions Practical).
  • The quiz duration is 80 minutes. An additional 10 mins is provided as a buffer for any issues that might arise during your quiz.
  • The quiz timer is set to 90 minutes, after which your answers will be saved and submitted automatically (unless you submit them sooner manually). The timer will continue to run if you exit the quiz.


General information relating to online quizzes:

  • The format may be a mixture of question types, for example: calculation, multiple choice, multiple answer, matching, ordering, fill in the blank/s, jumbled sentence/s, either/or (e.g. true/false), short answer, and short essay style questions.
  • Questions may be provided randomly from a pool; therefore, each student may receive a different but equivalent quiz.
  • The quiz will be marked electronically, correct answers will be awarded the marks indicated beside the question, incorrect answers will be awarded zero.
  • This is an individual assessment that you are required to undertake without any form of communication with other students.
  • As an online quiz undertaken in the venue of your choice, the quiz is open book.
  • This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of this assessment task will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI will provide only limited support and guidance.
  • See Learn.UQ (Blackboard) for more details and marking criteria.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission: The online quizzes will be completed electronically in the Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site from the venue of your choice.

assessments.task_description:
General information:

  • This quiz is to be completed in-person in the laboratories at UQ Dutton Park. 
  • The quiz is paper based with ONE attempt permitted
  • The quiz involves calculations related to compounding and dispensing liquid dosage forms, which you will practise in a series of practicals conducted regularly during the semester.
  • The quiz duration is 40 minutes.
  • Questions may be provided from a pool; therefore, each student may receive a different but equivalent quiz.
  • The marks allocated to each question are provided on the paper; answers may be awarded zero, part-marks, or full marks as applicable to each question.
  • This is an individual assessment that will be held under exam conditions.
  • See Learn.UQ (Blackboard) for more details and marking criteria.

Items that may be brought into the quiz (some of these are required for the Mock Compounding Skills Assessment that follows the quiz):

  • Your Student ID.
  • Laboratory coat, closed-in shoes and safety glasses are mandatory.
  • Calculators must be Casio FX82 series or UQ approved (labelled).
  • Australian Pharmaceutical Formulary (APF) - page tags are allowed, but annotations are not permitted.
  • Pens: all answers must be written in indelible pen, not pencil and not erasable pen. Mistakes must be neatly crossed through, do not use whiteout.

Items that may NOT be brought into the quiz:

  • any other items, including any electronic devices.

Materials that will be supplied:

  • The question sheets (including space to provide answers).
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission: The in-person quiz is a paper-based quiz that will be completed during the scheduled practical class at UQ Dutton Park in Week 8.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment task is to be completed in-person in the laboratories at UQ Dutton Park. 

Items that may be brought into the examination:

  • Your Student ID.
  • Laboratory coat, closed-in shoes and safety glasses are mandatory.
  • Calculators must be Casio FX82 series or UQ approved (labelled).
  • Australian Pharmaceutical Formulary (APF) - page tags are allowed, but annotations are not permitted.
  • Pens: all answers must be written in indelible pen, not pencil and not erasable pen. Mistakes must be neatly crossed through, do not use whiteout.

Items that may NOT be brought into the examination:

  • any other items, including any electronic devices.

Materials that will be supplied:

  • Part A: all ingredients and equipment required for the product that you will prepare and dispense, the prescription details, a compounding worksheet; one copy of the current edition of the APF per laboratory.
  • Part B: the question sheets and any relevant chemical information or formulae.

Instructions:

You will have 2 hours to complete both Parts A and B.

Part A is worth 50% of the available marks. In Part A you will work independently to prepare and dispense one assigned prescription. You will complete appropriate calculations, prepare the product, fill out a compounding worksheet, and label the product.

  • Complete the compounding worksheet as you go. Ingredient weights and volumes entered into the compounding worksheet MUST match the value on the balance or in the measuring cylinder and MUST be checked by an invigilator. Raise your hand when you need an invigilator to check and sign against your entries.
  • Prepare a suitable label and apply it to the product.
  • To pass Part A, your product must be of acceptable quality to be supplied to a patient. When you consider your product is ready to be supplied, submit the labelled product and compounding worksheet for assessment.
  • Three components are marked, i.e. the product, the label, and the compounding worksheet. A passing grade is achieved when all three components are of acceptable quality for the medication to be dispensed to a patient.

Part B is worth 50% of the available marks. In Part B you will complete calculations and answer questions regarding the compounded product and other concepts covered in the course. The marks allocated to each question are provided on the paper; answers may be awarded zero, part-marks, or full marks as applicable to each question.

See Learn.UQ (Blackboard) for more details, practice papers, and marking criteria.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission: The product, compounding worksheet and answers to the questions will be submitted during the examination.

learning_activities.topic:
Module 1 - Drug Analysis Practical

Three-hour practical in the laboratories at UQ Dutton Park campus. Working in a team, you will test paracetamol tablets to estimate their content of paracetamol using the Assay of Content test from the British Pharmacopoeia (BP).


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 1 - Drug Analysis Practical Three-hour practical in the laboratories at UQ Dutton Park campus. Working in a team, you will test paracetamol tablets to estimate their content of paracetamol using the Assay of Content test from the British Pharmacopoeia (BP).

learning_activities.topic:
Module 2 - Dispersions Practical

Three-hour practical in the laboratories at UQ Dutton Park campus. Working in a team, you will consider how important is it to shake the bottle of a dispersion formulation. Specifically, you will prepare aspirin suspension then investigate the variation in dose that a patient would receive when taking your product. You will evaluate your aspirin suspension using the British Pharmacopoeia (BP) test for content uniformity of liquid dosage forms.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05
